elements.content: Three new coordination polymers (CPs) have been synthesized by employing a bifunctional ligand, formulated as {Zn­(bppCOO)2} n (1), {Cu­(bppCOO)2} n (2), and {Co­(bppCOO)­(HCOO)­(H2O)} n ­·n1.5H2O (3) (where bppCOOH = 2,6-bis­(pyrazol-1-yl)­pyridine-4-carboxylic acid). Compounds 1 and 3 are obtained under hydrothermal conditions, whereas compound 2 is achieved when compound {Zn­(bppCOO)2} n (1) undergoes a direct metal exchange process with Cu­(II)-salt in a quantitative single crystal to single crystal transformation process (solid−liquid interface reaction), retaining its structural integrity. Thus, compounds 1 and 2 are structurally isomorphous. The deprotonated form of bppCOOH ligand links adjacent metal centers by utilizing both carboxylate and tridentate N donors to form one-dimensional coordination polymers. All the compounds 1–3, are well characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, CHNS, and thermogravimetric analyses. Finally, all three compounds are characterized unambiguously by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. We have demonstrated that the compound {Co­(bppCOO)­(HCOO)­(H2O)} n ­·n1.5H2O (3) having Co­(II) coordinated water has potential in exhibiting electrocatalytic water oxidation at a neutral pH.
elements.clean_text: Three new coordination polymers (CPs) have been synthesized by employing a bifunctional ligand, formulated as {Zn(bppCOO)2} n  (1), {Cu(bppCOO)2} n  (2), and {Co(bppCOO)(HCOO)(H2O)} n ⋅n1.5H2O (3) (where bppCOOH = 2,6-bis(pyrazol-1-yl)pyridine-4-carboxylic acid). Compounds 1 and 3 are obtained under hydrothermal conditions, whereas compound 2 is achieved when compound {Zn(bppCOO)2} n  (1) undergoes a direct metal exchange process with Cu(II)-salt in a quantitative single crystal to single crystal transformation process (solid-liquid interface reaction), retaining its structural integrity. Thus, compounds 1 and 2 are structurally isomorphous. The deprotonated form of bppCOOH ligand links adjacent metal centers by utilizing both carboxylate and tridentate N donors to form one-dimensional coordination polymers. All the compounds 1-3, are well characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, CHNS, and thermogravimetric analyses. Finally, all three compounds are characterized unambiguously by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. We have demonstrated that the compound {Co(bppCOO)(HCOO)(H2O)} n ⋅n1.5H2O (3) having Co(II) coordinated water has potential in exhibiting electrocatalytic water oxidation at a neutral pH.

elements.content: Quantitative transmetalation conversion of compound {Zn­(bppCOO)2} (1) to {Cu­(bppCOO)2} (2) is achieved in a single crystal to single manner in a solid−liquid interface reaction, when the parent material (Zn-compound) is dispersed in copper nitrate solution of DMF at room temperature for 2 days. The compound 2 is well characterized by electron paramagnetic resonance, powder X-ray diffraction, single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), and inductively coupled plasma analysis. Structural analysis (SCXRD) reveals that compound 2 is isomorphous to 1. Interestingly, compound {Co­(bppCOO)­(HCOO)­(H2O)} n ­·n1.5H2O (3) is found be a potential material for electrochemical water oxidation, based on our preliminary results.
elements.clean_text: Quantitative transmetalation conversion of compound {Zn(bppCOO)2} (1) to {Cu(bppCOO)2} (2) is achieved in a single crystal to single manner in a solid-liquid interface reaction, when the parent material (Zn-compound) is dispersed in copper nitrate solution of DMF at room temperature for 2 days. The compound 2 is well characterized by electron paramagnetic resonance, powder X-ray diffraction, single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), and inductively coupled plasma analysis. Structural analysis (SCXRD) reveals that compound 2 is isomorphous to 1. Interestingly, compound {Co(bppCOO)(HCOO)(H2O)} n ⋅n1.5H2O (3) is found be a potential material for electrochemical water oxidation, based on our preliminary results.

elements.content:
Published as part of the Crystal Growth and Design Israel Goldberg Memorial virtual special issue

Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) are essentially polymeric structures achieved by the self-assembly process of the metal ion/ions with the organic ligand involving a coordination bond leading to diverse dimensionalities. They exhibit a hybrid nature of both the components (metal ion as well as organic ligand) involved in the relevant synthesis. CPs, in general, have attracted an enormous attention because of their versatile applications in the areas of gas storage and sequestration, magnetism, sensing, catalysis, luminescence, nonlinear optics (NLO), proton conductivity, drug delivery, and biomedicine. The judicious selection of the ligand systems enables the fine-tuning of ligand induced properties of the resulting materials. In contrast to the mixed-ligand system, commonly used to synthesize CPs, in which carboxylate (acid) ligands and N-donor linkers are utilized for constructing these materials (CPs), the multifunctional ligands (diverse functionalities in one molecule as a ligand) are of special interest due to their dual nature of being acidic along with the N-donor coordination capabilities leading to distinct structural features. In this regard, the bispyrazolylpyridine carboxylate (bppCOOH) ligand (), a bifunctional tridentate N-linker having a carboxylate group, is chosen in the present work to study the structural modularity in hydrothermal conditions. As shown in , this ligand has variable coordination abilities for metal centers. Even though we have employed this bifunctional ligand in a hydrothermal synthesis to obtain extended structures, it was used earlier by other research groups as a monofunctional tridentate N-chelating/bridging ligand to bind the metal ions resulting in isolated (not extended) structures. Interestingly, in the present study (hydrothermal condition), this ligand utilizes its both functionalities to link adjacent metal centers leading to the formation of coordination polymers having extended structures.

elements.clean_text: 1  Structural Drawing of the Bispyrazolylpyridine Carboxylic Acid Ligand (bppCOOH) Used for the Synthesis of Compounds 1-3

elements.content: In this article, we report three new coordination polymers (CPs): {Zn­(bppCOO)2} n (1), {Cu­(bppCOO)2} n (2), and {Co­(bppCOO)­(HCOO)­(H2O)} n ­·n1.5H2O (3) based on the bispyrazolylpyridine carboxylate ligand (bppCOOH, ) with Zn­(II), Cu­(II), and Co­(II), respectively. Compounds 1 and 3 are synthesized by the hydrothermal method; on the other hand, compound 2 is obtained by direct metal ion exchange (transmetalation: Zn2+ by Cu2+) reaction of 1 with cupric nitrate, dissolved in DMF. In particular, the single crystals of compound Zn­(bppCOO)2} n (1), suspended in cupric nitrate solution in DMF, undergo single crystal to single crystal (SCSC) transformation in a solid–liquid interface reaction to form single crystals of {Cu­(bppCOO)2} n (2) retaining the original structure of the pristine CP 1. The SCSC transformation, especially metal exchange reaction (transmetalation), has emerged as a new way of obtaining functional materials; those otherwise cannot be obtained in a self-assembly process of metal–ligand coordination in a one-pot synthesis. Most of these transformations involve Zn/Cd-based coordination polymeric structures that go to Cu-based analogues by transmetalation; this is because the copper analogues are relatively more stable (associated with stronger bonds) than Zn/Cd coordination polymers, which is also reflected in the irreversible nature of the relevant SCSC transformation.
elements.clean_text: In this article, we report three new coordination polymers (CPs): {Zn(bppCOO)2} n  (1), {Cu(bppCOO)2} n  (2), and {Co(bppCOO)(HCOO)(H2O)} n ⋅n1.5H2O (3) based on the bispyrazolylpyridine carboxylate ligand (bppCOOH, ) with Zn(II), Cu(II), and Co(II), respectively. Compounds 1 and 3 are synthesized by the hydrothermal method; on the other hand, compound 2 is obtained by direct metal ion exchange (transmetalation: Zn2+ by Cu2+) reaction of 1 with cupric nitrate, dissolved in DMF. In particular, the single crystals of compound Zn(bppCOO)2} n  (1), suspended in cupric nitrate solution in DMF, undergo single crystal to single crystal (SCSC) transformation in a solid-liquid interface reaction to form single crystals of {Cu(bppCOO)2} n  (2) retaining the original structure of the pristine CP 1. The SCSC transformation, especially metal exchange reaction (transmetalation), has emerged as a new way of obtaining functional materials; those otherwise cannot be obtained in a self-assembly process of metal-ligand coordination in a one-pot synthesis. Most of these transformations involve Zn/Cd-based coordination polymeric structures that go to Cu-based analogues by transmetalation; this is because the copper analogues are relatively more stable (associated with stronger bonds) than Zn/Cd coordination polymers, which is also reflected in the irreversible nature of the relevant SCSC transformation.

The formation of 2 is well proved by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), and inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis. All the compounds {Zn­(bppCOO)2} n (1), {Cu­(bppCOO)2} n (2), and {Co­(bppCOO)­(HCOO)­(H2O)} n ­·n1.5H2O (3) are unambiguously characterized by single crystal X-ray crystallography. They are additionally characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies, IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric (TG), and CHNS analyses. elements.content: All the chemicals and solvents were received as reagent grade and used without any further purification except the 2,6-bis­(pyrazol-1-yl)­pyridine-4-carboxylic acid ligand (bppCOOH), which was prepared according to the literature procedure. Elemental analyses were determined by using a FLASH EA series 1112 CHNS analyzer. Infrared spectra of solid samples were recorded as KBr pellets on a JASCO-5300 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a STA 409 PC under the flow of N2 gas at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1, in the temperature range of 40–800 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8-Advance diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα1 (1.5406 Å) and Kα2 (1.54439 Å) radiation. Compounds 1 and 3 were synthesized hydrothermally in 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel vessels (Thermocon, India). The electronic absorption spectra have been recorded in the solid state on a UV-2600 shimadzu UV–visible spectrophotometer at room temperature. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) imaging, with EDX spectroscopy was carried out on a Carl Zeiss model Ultra 55 microscope. EDX spectra and maps were recorded using Oxford Instruments X-MaxN SDD (50 mm2) system and INCA analysis software. All electrochemical experiments were conducted using a Zahner Zanium electrochemical workstation operated with Thales software.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the chemicals and solvents were received as reagent grade and used without any further purification except the 2,6-bis(pyrazol-1-yl)pyridine-4-carboxylic acid ligand (bppCOOH), which was prepared according to the literature procedure. Elemental analyses were determined by using a FLASH EA series 1112 CHNS analyzer. Infrared spectra of solid samples were recorded as KBr pellets on a JASCO-5300 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a STA 409 PC under the flow of N2 gas at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1, in the temperature range of 40-800 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8-Advance diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα1 (1.5406 Å) and Kα2 (1.54439 Å) radiation. Compounds 1 and 3 were synthesized hydrothermally in 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel vessels (Thermocon, India). The electronic absorption spectra have been recorded in the solid state on a UV-2600 shimadzu UV-visible spectrophotometer at room temperature. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) imaging, with EDX spectroscopy was carried out on a Carl Zeiss model Ultra 55 microscope. EDX spectra and maps were recorded using Oxford Instruments X-MaxN SDD (50 mm2) system and INCA analysis software. All electrochemical experiments were conducted using a Zahner Zanium electrochemical workstation operated with Thales software.

elements.content: The mixture of 29.7 mg of Zn­(NO3)2­·6H2O (0.1 mmol) and 25.5 mg (0.1 mmol) of bppCOOH ligand was added to a solvent mixture of 8.0 mL of distilled water and 2 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 3.7 by adding 0.5 N aqueous NaOH solution. Then the reaction vessel was sealed into stainless steel reactor and heated at 120 °C for 60 h. White block-shaped crystals of compound 1 were obtained by cooling the reaction mixture to room temperature over 25 h. Yield 60% (based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C24H16N10O4Zn (M r = 573.84): C, 50.23%; H, 2.81%; N, 24.41%. Found: C, 50.32%; H, 2.76%; N, 24.31%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3089, 1650, 1625, 1565, 1521, 1456, 1397, 1337, 1270, 1203, 1043, 950, 894, 779, 726, 645, 599.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound {Zn(bppCOO)2} n  (1)

The mixture of 29.7 mg of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.1 mmol) and 25.5 mg (0.1 mmol) of bppCOOH ligand was added to a solvent mixture of 8.0 mL of distilled water and 2 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 3.7 by adding 0.5 N aqueous NaOH solution. Then the reaction vessel was sealed into stainless steel reactor and heated at 120 °C for 60 h. White block-shaped crystals of compound 1 were obtained by cooling the reaction mixture to room temperature over 25 h. Yield 60% (based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C24H16N10O4Zn (M r = 573.84): C, 50.23%; H, 2.81%; N, 24.41%. Found: C, 50.32%; H, 2.76%; N, 24.31%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3089, 1650, 1625, 1565, 1521, 1456, 1397, 1337, 1270, 1203, 1043, 950, 894, 779, 726, 645, 599.

elements.content: Single crystals of compound {Zn­(bppCOO)2} n (1) were immersed in 0.05 M Cu­(NO3)2 solution of DMF for 2 days. At the end of one day, the solution was replaced with the freshly prepared one. After the reaction was completed, the compound {Cu­(bppCOO)2} n (2) was obtained by decanting the solution and washing with DMF many times. C24H16N10O4Cu (M r = 572.01): C, 50.39%; H, 2.81%; N, 24.48%. Found: C, 50.48%; H, 2.89%; N, 24.56%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3112, 2360, 1666, 1628, 1582, 1518, 1461, 1428, 1326, 1254, 1209, 1161, 1077, 1050, 973, 907, 827, 774, 733, 639, 599.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound {Cu(bppCOO)2} n  (2)

Single crystals of compound {Zn(bppCOO)2} n  (1) were immersed in 0.05 M Cu(NO3)2 solution of DMF for 2 days. At the end of one day, the solution was replaced with the freshly prepared one. After the reaction was completed, the compound {Cu(bppCOO)2} n  (2) was obtained by decanting the solution and washing with DMF many times. C24H16N10O4Cu (M r = 572.01): C, 50.39%; H, 2.81%; N, 24.48%. Found: C, 50.48%; H, 2.89%; N, 24.56%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3112, 2360, 1666, 1628, 1582, 1518, 1461, 1428, 1326, 1254, 1209, 1161, 1077, 1050, 973, 907, 827, 774, 733, 639, 599.

elements.content: The compound 3 was prepared in a procedure similar to that of compound 1 except that the Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol) was replaced with CoCl2·6H2O (23.79 mg, 0.1 mmol). In this case, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 5.2 by adding 0.5 N aqueous NaOH solution, and the reaction vessel was sealed into stainless steel reactor and heated at 120 °C for 60 h. After cooling to room temperature over 25 h, a clear pink color solution was obtained, which was kept at room temperature for slow evaporation of the solvent for 10–15 days. Pink-red colored good quality single crystals of compound 3 were developed during this period of time. C13H14N5O6.5Co (M r = 403.21): C, 38.72%; H, 3.5%; N, 17.37%. Found: C, 38.81%; H, 3.47%; N, 17.28%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3265, 1570, 1525, 1451, 1394, 1351, 1299, 1268, 1170, 1057, 969, 914, 790, 766, 744, 598.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound {Co(bppCOO)(HCOO)(H2O)} n ⋅n1.5H2O (3)

The compound 3 was prepared in a procedure similar to that of compound 1 except that the Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.1 mmol) was replaced with CoCl2⋅6H2O (23.79 mg, 0.1 mmol). In this case, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 5.2 by adding 0.5 N aqueous NaOH solution, and the reaction vessel was sealed into stainless steel reactor and heated at 120 °C for 60 h. After cooling to room temperature over 25 h, a clear pink color solution was obtained, which was kept at room temperature for slow evaporation of the solvent for 10-15 days. Pink-red colored good quality single crystals of compound 3 were developed during this period of time. C13H14N5O6.5Co (M r = 403.21): C, 38.72%; H, 3.5%; N, 17.37%. Found: C, 38.81%; H, 3.47%; N, 17.28%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3265, 1570, 1525, 1451, 1394, 1351, 1299, 1268, 1170, 1057, 969, 914, 790, 766, 744, 598.

elements.content: Data for single-crystals suitable for structural determination of all the compounds 1–3 were collected on a Bruker D8 Quest CCD diffractometer under a Mo–Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) graphite monochromatic X-ray beam with a crystal-to-detector distance of 40 mm. The data reduction was performed using Apex-II Software. Empirical absorption corrections using equivalent reflections were performed with the program SADABS. Structure solutions, and full-matrix least-squares refinement were carried out using standard crystallographic softwares for all the compounds. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms on the C atoms were introduced at calculated positions and were included in the refinement riding on their respective parent atoms. Attempts to locate hydrogen atoms for the solvent water molecules in the crystal structure of compound 3 through Fourier electron density map failed. However, no attempts were made to fix these atoms on their parent atoms. In case of compound 3, the O7 solvent molecule shows some disorder, and the projections of H atoms due to the steric factors are very close, which in turn results in PLAT260_Alert_2_B and PLAT430_Alert_2_B, respectively. Crystal data and structure refinement parameters for compounds 1–3 are summarized in , and selected bond lengths and bond angles are presented in Tables S1–S3 in the Supporting Information. CCDC 1875692, CCDC 1875693, and CCDC 1875694 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for compounds 1, 2, and 3 respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Structure Determination of the Compounds 1-3 

Data for single-crystals suitable for structural determination of all the compounds 1-3 were collected on a Bruker D8 Quest CCD diffractometer under a Mo-Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) graphite monochromatic X-ray beam with a crystal-to-detector distance of 40 mm. The data reduction was performed using Apex-II Software. Empirical absorption corrections using equivalent reflections were performed with the program SADABS. Structure solutions, and full-matrix least-squares refinement were carried out using standard crystallographic softwares for all the compounds. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms on the C atoms were introduced at calculated positions and were included in the refinement riding on their respective parent atoms. Attempts to locate hydrogen atoms for the solvent water molecules in the crystal structure of compound 3 through Fourier electron density map failed. However, no attempts were made to fix these atoms on their parent atoms. In case of compound 3, the O7 solvent molecule shows some disorder, and the projections of H atoms due to the steric factors are very close, which in turn results in PLAT260_Alert_2_B and PLAT430_Alert_2_B, respectively. Crystal data and structure refinement parameters for compounds 1-3 are summarized in , and selected bond lengths and bond angles are presented in Tables S1-S3 in the Supporting Information. CCDC 1875692, CCDC 1875693, and CCDC 1875694 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for compounds 1, 2, and 3 respectively.

elements.content: As shown in reaction , compound {Zn­(bppCOO)2} n (1) can directly be obtained starting from zinc nitrate salt and the bppCOOH in an DMF–water mixed solvent (when an effective pH of 2.5 was observed). NaOH solution was subsequently added to deprotonate the bppCOOH ligand, whereby the pH of the resulting mixture went up to 3.70. When we tried to obtain the copper analogue [{Cu­(bppCOO)2} n (2)] of compound 1 by the same procedure using cupric nitrate, we could not isolate/obtain compound 2. However, the transmetalation reaction of compound 1 with Cu­(II) nitrate solution in DMF via single crystal to single crystal transformation affords compound 2 in a solid–liquid interface reaction (as shown in ). Thus, the transmetalation, in the present study, is the only route to obtain compound {Cu­(bppCOO)2} n (2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

As shown in reaction , compound {Zn(bppCOO)2} n  (1) can directly be obtained starting from zinc nitrate salt and the bppCOOH in an DMF-water mixed solvent (when an effective pH of 2.5 was observed). NaOH solution was subsequently added to deprotonate the bppCOOH ligand, whereby the pH of the resulting mixture went up to 3.70. When we tried to obtain the copper analogue [{Cu(bppCOO)2} n  (2)] of compound 1 by the same procedure using cupric nitrate, we could not isolate/obtain compound 2. However, the transmetalation reaction of compound 1 with Cu(II) nitrate solution in DMF via single crystal to single crystal transformation affords compound 2 in a solid-liquid interface reaction (as shown in ). Thus, the transmetalation, in the present study, is the only route to obtain compound {Cu(bppCOO)2} n  (2).

elements.content: On the other hand, compound {Co­(bppCOO)­(HCOO)­(H2O)} n ­·n1.5H2O (3) can be obtained from the same recipe (), but with cobalt chloride salt (instead of cobalt nitrate salt). Interestingly, in this particular synthesis, the DMF solvent gets decomposed into formic acid and dimethylamine (which can be released from the reaction mixture as a dimethylamine gas). The in situ formed formic acid coordinates to the cobalt­(II) center in compound 3 as a formate anion ligand. Thus, the synthesis of compound 3 is not only important for obtaining a coordination polymer, but also it offers a value added organic conversion of DMF solvent into formic acid. ( CH 3 ) 2 NCHO + H 2 O → ( CH 3 ) 2 NH + HCOOH

The in situ formed formic acid coordinates to the cobalt(II) center in compound 3 as a formate anion ligand. Thus, the synthesis of compound 3 is not only important for obtaining a coordination polymer, but also it offers a value added organic conversion of DMF solvent into formic acid. elements.content: Single crystal structural analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. Asymmetric unit contains two bppCOO– ligands and one Zn­(II) ion (a). In the overall crystal structure, Zn­(II) ion exists in distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry, defined by three N atoms from one bppCOO– unit and one oxygen atom from another bppCOO– in the plane. The fifth coordination position is occupied by oxygen atom from third ligand (b). The Zn­(II) center lies above the plane by a distance of 0.459 Å. All the Zn–N bond distances are in the range of 2.124–2.231 Å, and the Zn–O bond distances are in the range of 1.961–1.963 Å. In the present study, the bppCOO– acid acts as a bifunctional ligand since it possesses a carboxylate functional group as well as N-donor atoms in its structure. However, two different types of bppCOO– ligands exist in the crystal structure of 1, one being bifunctional (type I) and the other one acts as monofunctional ligand (type II). The type I ligand, from one side, connects to one Zn­(II) center through the carboxylate group and from other side, the ligand coordinates to the neighboring Zn­(II) center by one pyridyl nitrogen atom and two pyrazolyl nitrogen atoms in a tridentate chelate fashion to result in a Zn­(II)-bppCOO– one-dimensional (1D) chain (b). On the other hand, type II ligand coordinates to the Zn­(II) center in a monodentate fashion through the oxygen atom of the carboxylate group, as if it is hanging from the chain (c). Since compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous to each other (difference in the metal center), the crystal structure of compound 2 is not discussed in detail.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

{Zn(bppCOO)2} n  (1)

Single crystal structural analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. Asymmetric unit contains two bppCOO- ligands and one Zn(II) ion (a). In the overall crystal structure, Zn(II) ion exists in distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry, defined by three N atoms from one bppCOO- unit and one oxygen atom from another bppCOO- in the plane. The fifth coordination position is occupied by oxygen atom from third ligand (b). The Zn(II) center lies above the plane by a distance of 0.459 Å. All the Zn-N bond distances are in the range of 2.124-2.231 Å, and the Zn-O bond distances are in the range of 1.961-1.963 Å. In the present study, the bppCOO- acid acts as a bifunctional ligand since it possesses a carboxylate functional group as well as N-donor atoms in its structure. However, two different types of bppCOO- ligands exist in the crystal structure of 1, one being bifunctional (type I) and the other one acts as monofunctional ligand (type II). The type I ligand, from one side, connects to one Zn(II) center through the carboxylate group and from other side, the ligand coordinates to the neighboring Zn(II) center by one pyridyl nitrogen atom and two pyrazolyl nitrogen atoms in a tridentate chelate fashion to result in a Zn(II)-bppCOO- one-dimensional (1D) chain (b). On the other hand, type II ligand coordinates to the Zn(II) center in a monodentate fashion through the oxygen atom of the carboxylate group, as if it is hanging from the chain (c). Since compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous to each other (difference in the metal center), the crystal structure of compound 2 is not discussed in detail.

elements.content: Compound 3, a cobalt based coordination polymer, crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. Further structural analysis discloses that the asymmetric unit consists of one Co­(II) metal ion and one bppCOO– ligand, one formate ion, one coordinated water moiety, and one and half lattice water molecules (a). The ligand assumes a similar coordination mode as that of type I ligand in compound 1. The Co­(II) ion assumes the distorted octahedral geometry, which is defined by three nitrogen atoms from one bppCOO– ligand and one oxygen atom from a second molecule of bppCOO– ligand in the equatorial plane, whereas one of the axial positions is occupied by one oxygen from a coordinated water molecule, and the other apical position is satisfied by the oxygen atom from formate anion. The Co–O bond distances are in the range of 2.069–2.114 Å, and the Co–N distances lie between 2.151 and 2.246 Å. In the crystal structure, the Co­(II) metal ions (compound 3) are arranged linearly in the crystallographic b axis that are separated by the bppCOO– ligand; in other words, each Co­(II) ion connects two bppCOO– (from opposite sides: one side with three N donors of one bppCOO– and other side with oxygen donor of other bppCOO– linker) along the crystallographic b axis leading to the formation of a one-dimensional (1D) chain (b). The Co–Co separation in this chain is found to be 9.102 Å. Further, along this 1D chain, each cobalt is additionally coordinated to one water molecule and one formate molecule (c). The classical hydrogen bonding is observed between the coordinated water and formate anion present in the adjacent 1D chains to form a 2D supramolecular architecture [see Supporting Information, Figure S2a]; the coordinated water molecule forms two hydrogen bonds: one with the formate anion in the same 2D layer (O3–H3B···O5) and the other with the carboxylate oxygen (O3–H3A···O2) in the oppositely running 2D layer to result in a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure. Along with these interactions, the nonclassical hydrogen bonds (C3C–H3C···O4 and C10J–H10J···O4) are observed between C–H moieties from one layer and formate oxygens from the other layer offering compound 3 an overall 3D supramolecular structure (d). Within this supramolecular assembly, the hydrogen bonding between lattice water molecules (O6 and O7) results in a zigzag water chain, where O6 forms two hydrogen bonds, one with the coordinated water (O5) and the other with the symmetrically related same water molecule (O6): they are O6–H6A···O5 and O6–H6B···O6, respectively. Conversely, O7 forms hydrogen bonding with O6 (O7–H7A···O6) and carboxylate oxygen O1A (O7–H7B···O1A) (Figure S2b, Supporting Information). Apart from these, intramolecular C–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions between formate and carboxylate group can be seen (C13–H13···O1A and C9I–H9I···O1A) as shown in Figure S2c (Supporting Information). contains overall hydrogen bonding interaction parameters (Å, °) involved in the formation of supramolecular architecture in the crystal structure of compound 3.

All three compounds show 1D polymeric structures in their crystal structures. But in the crystal structures of compounds 1 and 2, the metal centers Zn­(II) and Cu­(II) exist in penta-coordinated square pyramidal geometry, whereas, in compound 3, the metal center Co­(II) forms hexacoordinated octahedral motif. Another important observation is that the metal centers in compounds 1 and 2 are bridged by one bppCOO– ligand along the crystallographic a axis, whereas, in compound 3, the chain axis is the b axis.

elements.content: Inspired by metal exchange reactions on Zn-based compounds, we performed the transmetalation reaction on compound 1 by dispersing it in 0.05 M Cu­(NO3)2 solution in DMF. The color of the Zn-compound crystals change with time revealing the conversion of 1 to 2. The metal ion exchange and structural integrity were investigated by EPR, EDX, PXRD techniques, and finally by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) studies.
elements.clean_text:
Transmetalation via SCSC Transformation: Structural Transformation of 1 into 2 

Inspired by metal exchange reactions on Zn-based compounds, we performed the transmetalation reaction on compound 1 by dispersing it in 0.05 M Cu(NO3)2 solution in DMF. The color of the Zn-compound crystals change with time revealing the conversion of 1 to 2. The metal ion exchange and structural integrity were investigated by EPR, EDX, PXRD techniques, and finally by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) studies.

elements.content: The powdered EPR spectrum of compound 2 was recorded at room temperature to investigate the metal exchange process in compound 1. The presence of an EPR signal (a) in the spectrum of compound 2 ensures the existence of paramagnetic Cu­(II) in the resulting transformed crystals of compound 2. As shown in a, an axial EPR spectrum of 2 consists of two signals belonging to g ∥ and g ⊥ components of g-factor, where g ∥ = 2.289 and g ⊥ = 2.094 respectively, representing axial feature, g ∥ > g ⊥> g e (g e = 2.0023). In general, an axial EPR spectrum is expected for Cu­(II) compounds having either an elongated octahedral, square pyramidal, or square planar coordination geometry around the Cu­(II) metal ion. The SCXRD analysis (b) of compound 2 reveals that the compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous to each other. Thus, Cu­(II) is pentacoordinated and exists in square pyramidal geometry, consistent with an axial EPR signal. Further, the bulk purity of the transformed crystals (compound 2) is ensured by the PXRD measurements. The experimental PXRD pattern of compound 2 is in good agreement with the PXRD pattern of the 1, signifying the fact that there is no new phase in 2 (see Supporting Information, Figure S1a). The SCXRD data were taken after complete conversion of compound 1 into 2. Since compound 2 {Cu­(bppCOO)2} n crystallizes in the same space group “triclinic P1̅” as that of pristine compound 1, {Zn­(bppCOO)2} n , the number of molecules in the asymmetric unit, geometry around the metal ion, bond lengths, and bond angles in the coordination sphere are almost similar to the ones present in 1, confirming that compound 2 retains its structure during the transmetalation conversion (b). Single crystal images of compounds 1 and 2 clearly show a color change from colorless to green, as shown in c. The transmetalation reactions of compound 1, with other transition metal ions having similar ionic radii, e.g., Mn­(II), Fe­(II), Co­(II), and Ni­(II), are also performed, since the size and ability to adopt similar geometry of the incoming metal ion are a key factor in metal exchange reaction. However, there is no color change observed for Mn­(II), Fe­(II), Co­(II), and Ni­(II), indicating nonoccurrence of metal exchange processes with these metal ions; the EDX plots of compound 1 do not show the presence of any appreciable amount of these metal ions. These results conclude that only Cu­(II) forms a stable complex, i.e., compound 2. This may be due to an extra stability obtained by John-Teller distortion (driving force) in the resulting copper compound 2.

elements.content: EDX spectroscopy studies reveal that the complete conversion (in the present transmetalation process) takes place in 2 days as shown in the kinetic plot (; see also Supporting Information, Figure S3 for EDX results). The metal ion percentages (%) of Cu­(II) and Zn­(II) were estimated in the transforming material as a function of time, after every 7 h of period. This reveals that more than 65% of Zn­(II) ions in 1 were replaced by Cu­(II) in 24 h, whereas complete conversion has been observed in 48 h. ICP results showed that there is no significant amount (1%) of Zn­(II) left in compound 2 (see Supporting Information, Figure S4).

elements.content: The UV–visible spectrum of compound 2 shows two ligand centered bands in the high energy region along with the broad band in the range of 600–850 nm due to the d–d transitions of Cu­(II) metal (vide infra). As per relevant literature, in the present study also, the transmetalated copper compound 2 is more stable than that of zinc compound 1 (vide infra: TGA studies).

elements.content: Diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of all the compounds were recorded on powdered samples at room temperature. The normalized UV–visible spectra of compounds 1–3 along with ligand spectrum are shown in . All the compounds exhibit two peaks in the high energy region (I and II; a): the absorption maxima I (λmax) are positioned at 266, 268, 243 nm for 1, 2, and 3, respectively; the absorption maxima II are 325, 332, and 326 nm for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. In addition to these two types of peaks, compounds 2 and 3 possess a broad band in the region of 550–850 nm and 450–600 nm, respectively (a). The high energy bands [I and II] in all the three compounds are attributed to the intraligand charge transfer transitions due to their very close resemblance to those of free ligand, i.e., bppCOOH (λmax; 261 and 327 nm) (b). The low energy bands in the case of compounds 2 and 3 are ascribed due to d–d transitions of the metal ions Cu­(II) and Co­(II), respectively.

elements.content: The oxidation of water to dioxygen, 2H2O → 4H+ + O2 + 4e–, is considered to be the most remarkable reaction, as far as natural life support on the earth surface is concerned. We have recently demonstrated that metal coordinated water molecule, i.e., M–OH2 functionality, is able to show electrocatalytic water oxidation. We have argued that the two successive one-electron oxidations of a MII–OH2 moiety produces reactive MIVO species that oxidizes water to dioxygen. As shown in , in the crystal structure of compound 3, the cobalt­(II) ion is coordinated to a water molecule in a monodentate fashion. Overall, in the concerned crystal structure, each cobalt along the 1D coordination polymer has one water coordination. A preliminary electrochemical investigation on compound 3, having a MII–OH2 moiety, shows that compound 3 undergoes a quasireversible oxidation at around 0.81 V vs Ag-AgCl reference electrode (in 0.1 M KCl, scan rate 100 mV/s), followed by an onset for water oxidation as shown in a. This oxidative response at 0.81 V can tentatively be assigned to the CoIV/CoII couple.
elements.clean_text:
Compound {Co(bppCOO)(HCOO)(H2O)} n ⋅n1.5H2O (3): A Potential Elecrocatalyst for Water Oxidation

The oxidation of water to dioxygen, 2H2O → 4H+ + O2 + 4e-, is considered to be the most remarkable reaction, as far as natural life support on the earth surface is concerned. We have recently demonstrated that metal coordinated water molecule, i.e., M-OH2 functionality, is able to show electrocatalytic water oxidation. We have argued that the two successive one-electron oxidations of a MII-OH2 moiety produces reactive MIVO species that oxidizes water to dioxygen. As shown in , in the crystal structure of compound 3, the cobalt(II) ion is coordinated to a water molecule in a monodentate fashion. Overall, in the concerned crystal structure, each cobalt along the 1D coordination polymer has one water coordination. A preliminary electrochemical investigation on compound 3, having a MII-OH2 moiety, shows that compound 3 undergoes a quasireversible oxidation at around 0.81 V vs Ag-AgCl reference electrode (in 0.1 M KCl, scan rate 100 mV/s), followed by an onset for water oxidation as shown in a. This oxidative response at 0.81 V can tentatively be assigned to the CoIV/CoII couple.

elements.content: This experiment was done by coating 10 μL of the sample of compound 3 on the glassy carbon working electrode in a heterogeneous manner. The same experiment was also performed in nonaqueous medium (MeCN, using tetrabutyl ammonium tetrafluoroborate as supporting electrolyte) with sequential addition of water (microliter portions). We have found that, as we add the water (in microliter portions) sequentially, the current height increases accordingly as shown in b. This indicates that compound 3 can act as a electrocatalyst for water oxidation. This is our preliminary result on electrochemistry in this work. Further work is needed to comprehend more about this water oxidation.

elements.content: Compound 2, in contrast to compound 1, displays a quasi-reversible couple at 0.16 V against Ag/AgCl. This can be assigned to a Cu­(II)/Cu­(I) redox couple as shown b. Thus, compounds 1 and 2, both of which lack a M-OH2 functional site, do not show any electrochemical water oxidation. This indirectly proves that a metal-aqua coordination (a M-OH2 functionality) is needed for such a system to exhibit electrocatalytic water oxidation. On the other hand, compound {Co­(bppCOO)­(HCOO)­(H2O)} n ­·n1.5H2O (3) having M-OH2 functionality does have the potential to act as an electrocatalyst for water oxidation.

elements.content: In conclusion, a bifunctional ligand (2,6-bis­(pyrazol-1-yl)­pyridine-4-carboxylic acid-bppCOOH) is utilized to construct three new coordination polymers (CPs), {Zn­(bppCOO)2} n (1), {Cu­(bppCOO)2} n (2), and {Co­(bppCOO)­(HCOO)­(H2O)} n ­·n1.5H2O­(3). In contrast to 1 and 3, which are obtained under hydrothermal conditions, compound 2 has been obtained from 1 through the SCSC fashion in a quantitative metal exchange process in a solid–liquid interface reaction. Crystal structures of all the compounds are unambiguously determined by SCXRD analysis, followed by PXRD, IR spectroscopy, UV–visible spectroscopy, CHNS, and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. The compound 2 was further confirmed by EPR spectroscopy, EDX, and ICP analysis. The SCXRD analysis of 1–3 reveals that, in all three compounds a 1D metal-bppCOO– ligand chain exists. TGA reveals that copper compound 2 {Cu­(bppCOO)2} n , derived from zinc compound {Zn­(bppCOO)2} n (1) by a transmetalation reaction, is found to be more stable than that of parent material 1. The solid state electronic properties of all the compounds are studied in detail. Finally, we have demonstrated that the compound 3, having Co-OH2 functionality, has the potential to oxidize water electrocatalytically as a preliminary result. Detailed kinetics work on this water oxidation is in progress in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, a bifunctional ligand (2,6-bis(pyrazol-1-yl)pyridine-4-carboxylic acid-bppCOOH) is utilized to construct three new coordination polymers (CPs), {Zn(bppCOO)2} n  (1), {Cu(bppCOO)2} n  (2), and {Co(bppCOO)(HCOO)(H2O)} n ⋅n1.5H2O(3). In contrast to 1 and 3, which are obtained under hydrothermal conditions, compound 2 has been obtained from 1 through the SCSC fashion in a quantitative metal exchange process in a solid-liquid interface reaction. Crystal structures of all the compounds are unambiguously determined by SCXRD analysis, followed by PXRD, IR spectroscopy, UV-visible spectroscopy, CHNS, and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. The compound 2 was further confirmed by EPR spectroscopy, EDX, and ICP analysis. The SCXRD analysis of 1-3 reveals that, in all three compounds a 1D metal-bppCOO- ligand chain exists. TGA reveals that copper compound 2 {Cu(bppCOO)2} n , derived from zinc compound {Zn(bppCOO)2} n  (1) by a transmetalation reaction, is found to be more stable than that of parent material 1. The solid state electronic properties of all the compounds are studied in detail. Finally, we have demonstrated that the compound 3, having Co-OH2 functionality, has the potential to oxidize water electrocatalytically as a preliminary result. Detailed kinetics work on this water oxidation is in progress in our laboratory.

The mixture of 29.7 mg of Zn­(NO3)2­·6H2O (0.1 mmol) and 25.5 mg (0.1 mmol) of bppCOOH ligand was added to a solvent mixture of 8.0 mL of distilled water and 2 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 3.7 by adding 0.5 N aqueous NaOH solution. Then the reaction vessel was sealed into stainless steel reactor and heated at 120 °C for 60 h. White block-shaped crystals of compound 1 were obtained by cooling the reaction mixture to room temperature over 25 h. Yield 60% (based on Zn). Anal. Calcd for C24H16N10O4Zn (M r = 573.84): C, 50.23%; H, 2.81%; N, 24.41%. Found: C, 50.32%; H, 2.76%; N, 24.31%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3089, 1650, 1625, 1565, 1521, 1456, 1397, 1337, 1270, 1203, 1043, 950, 894, 779, 726, 645, 599.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>{</bold>Cu­(bppCOO)<sub>2</sub>}<italic> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>2</bold>)

Single crystals of compound {Zn­(bppCOO)2} n (1) were immersed in 0.05 M Cu­(NO3)2 solution of DMF for 2 days. At the end of one day, the solution was replaced with the freshly prepared one. After the reaction was completed, the compound {Cu­(bppCOO)2} n (2) was obtained by decanting the solution and washing with DMF many times. C24H16N10O4Cu (M r = 572.01): C, 50.39%; H, 2.81%; N, 24.48%. Found: C, 50.48%; H, 2.89%; N, 24.56%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3112, 2360, 1666, 1628, 1582, 1518, 1461, 1428, 1326, 1254, 1209, 1161, 1077, 1050, 973, 907, 827, 774, 733, 639, 599.

Synthesis of Compound {Co­(bppCOO)­(HCOO)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub>­·<italic>n</italic>1.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

The compound 3 was prepared in a procedure similar to that of compound 1 except that the Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol) was replaced with CoCl2·6H2O (23.79 mg, 0.1 mmol). In this case, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 5.2 by adding 0.5 N aqueous NaOH solution, and the reaction vessel was sealed into stainless steel reactor and heated at 120 °C for 60 h. After cooling to room temperature over 25 h, a clear pink color solution was obtained, which was kept at room temperature for slow evaporation of the solvent for 10–15 days. Pink-red colored good quality single crystals of compound 3 were developed during this period of time. C13H14N5O6.5Co (M r = 403.21): C, 38.72%; H, 3.5%; N, 17.37%. Found: C, 38.81%; H, 3.47%; N, 17.28%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3265, 1570, 1525, 1451, 1394, 1351, 1299, 1268, 1170, 1057, 969, 914, 790, 766, 744, 598.

Beyond these temperatures, all the compounds undergo a continuous weight loss, resulting in the collapse of the framework material due to the decomposition of the organic ligand, i.e., bppCOO–, present in the crystals of compounds 1–3.

The cyclic voltammetric studies of compounds {Zn­(bppCOO)2} n (1) and {Cu­(bppCOO)2} n (2) are also performed to study their electrochemical properties by coating respective samples (10 μL) on GC working electrode in 0.1 M KCl solution at a scan rate of 100 mV/s using Ag/AgCl as reference electrode (sample preparation is given in page 7, Supporting Information). As shown in a, the CV of compound 1 shows a reduction response at −1.1 V, which can be attributed to the reduction of associated ligand by comparing the CV of the free ligand bppCOOH (−0.91 V), recorded separately (Figure S5, Supporting Information); the shift in the potential may be due to the complexation of the ligand with the metal center, i.e., Zn­(II).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Electronic Spectra of Compounds 1-3 

Diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of all the compounds were recorded on powdered samples at room temperature. The normalized UV-visible spectra of compounds 1-3 along with ligand spectrum are shown in . All the compounds exhibit two peaks in the high energy region (I and II; a): the absorption maxima I (λmax) are positioned at 266, 268, 243 nm for 1, 2, and 3, respectively; the absorption maxima II are 325, 332, and 326 nm for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. In addition to these two types of peaks, compounds 2 and 3 possess a broad band in the region of 550-850 nm and 450-600 nm, respectively (a). The high energy bands [I and II] in all the three compounds are attributed to the intraligand charge transfer transitions due to their very close resemblance to those of free ligand, i.e., bppCOOH (λmax; 261 and 327 nm) (b). The low energy bands in the case of compounds 2 and 3 are ascribed due to d-d transitions of the metal ions Cu(II) and Co(II), respectively.

Thermogravimetric analyses () are performed under the flow of N2 atmosphere from 40 to 800 °C on powdered samples to examine the thermal stability of the synthesized compounds. The TGA profiles of compounds 1, 2, and 3 show good thermal stability up to 320, 395, and 317 °C, respectively. As it is anticipated, the copper compound 2 shows an extra thermal stability by 75 °C compared to that of zinc compound 1, revealing the fact that the Cu(II) coordination polymers (CPs) form stabler structures than corresponding Zn(II)-CPs.

Although compound 3 is a 1D coordination polymer as that of 1 and 2, it forms a completely different structure in which the Co(II) is coordinated by one water and one formate anion along with 1.5 molecules of lattice water per formula unit. The TGA curve of compound 3 displays two-step degradation processes. In the first step, the weight loss (6.6%) in the temperature range of 40-90 °C corresponds to the loss of 1.5 lattice water molecules (calcd 6.78%). In the next step, the weight loss (15.43%) in the range of 90-316 °C is equivalent to the loss of coordinated water and formate anion (calcd 15.62%)  as shown in . Beyond these temperatures, all the compounds undergo a continuous weight loss, resulting in the collapse of the framework material due to the decomposition of the organic ligand, i.e., bppCOO-, present in the crystals of compounds 1-3.

The cyclic voltammetric studies of compounds {Zn(bppCOO)2} n  (1) and {Cu(bppCOO)2} n  (2) are also performed to study their electrochemical properties by coating respective samples (10 μL) on GC working electrode in 0.1 M KCl solution at a scan rate of 100 mV/s using Ag/AgCl as reference electrode (sample preparation is given in page 7, Supporting Information). As shown in a, the CV of compound 1 shows a reduction response at -1.1 V, which can be attributed to the reduction of associated ligand by comparing the CV of the free ligand bppCOOH (-0.91 V), recorded separately (Figure S5, Supporting Information); the shift in the potential may be due to the complexation of the ligand with the metal center, i.e., Zn(II).
